presentation.title: Carbon sequestration and storage
presentation.runninghead: The values accrued by any beneficiary of CO2 sequestration and storage
presentation.description: The values accrued by any beneficiary of CO2 sequestration and storage

page.name: CO2 sequestration and storage
page.title: General description
page.description:
This storyline computes estimates carbon sequestration by terrestrial ecosystems - the net removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere and the avoidance of CO2 emissions from terrestrial ecosystems into the atmosphere via fire or deforestation. CO2 uptake from the atmosphere largely occurs via photosynthesis. This carbon is stored as plant biomass (in the trunks, branches, leaves and roots of the plants) and organic matter in the soil. Terrestrial carbon sequestration depends on a series of factors including climatic conditions, vegetation structure and successional stage, and land use practices.

In ARIES, we distinguish between ecosystem sources where carbon sequestration occurs. We also map sinks, or areas at risk of releasing stored carbon, largely via fire or deforestation. By subtracting the amount of stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in a region of interest, we are left with the carbon remaining available to offset anthropogenic emissions. These greenhouse gas emitters are the beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage. Since greenhouse gas emitters benefit from the waste absorption capacity of the biosphere, carbon sequestration and storage can be divided among emitters. Existing and proposed systems to cap and assign property rights to atmospheric greenhouse gas emissions use this framework. In other words:

Carbon sequestration (source) – stored carbon release (sink) = carbon available to offset emissions (use)

By mapping levels of carbon sequestration, stored carbon release, and anthropogenic emissions in a common unit (tonnes C/ha.yr), we can fully describe regional carbon balances – the level of a region’s net release or uptake of atmospheric CO2. This will become increasingly important as local, state, and national governments continue to inventory greenhouse gas emissions and implement strategies to address climate change. Use of ecosystem carbon sequestration is rival and occurs at the global scale through atmospheric mixing.
page.see-also:
The carbon section of the ARIES web site
IPCC web site
page.credits:
Model and data development: Ken Bagstad, Ferdinando Villa, Gary Johnson, Sergey Krivov, Brian Voigt.
Additional contributors: Ted Auch, Mark Casias, Sam Gorton, Jennifer Wright, Dave Batker, Jim Pittman, Paula Swedeen. Miroslav Honzak.
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.title: Carbon Sequestration
page.name: Atmospheric CO2 removed
page.description:
CO2 sequestered. The amount of carbon taken up by vegetation and soils and added to biotic and soil carbon stocks. This is the quantity available for mitigating anthropogenic carbon emissions.

Role in models

This map is the most relevant output of the ARIES carbon model. The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of rising atmospheric CO2 is indicated by the amount of carbon sequestered by vegetation and soil.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon sequestered per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of carbon. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server when the area was selected.
page.see-also:
The carbon section of the ARIES web site
IPCC web site
page.runninghead: Tonnes of C sequestered by vegetation and soils

page.name: Stored carbon release
page.title: Release of stored carbon
page.description:
The total emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change, excluding emissions from fossil fuel combustion.

Role in models

This map is an output of the ARIES carbon model. The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of climate change is reduced when stored carbon in vegetation or soils is released.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon released per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the distribution probability of the amount of carbon released, based on the amount of stored carbon and the probability of fire and/or deforestation. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server when the area was selected.
page.runninghead: The total emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change.

page.name: Carbon emitted
page.title: CO2 emission from human activity
page.description:
The beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage are greenhouse gas emitters who release CO2 into the atmosphere, relying on ecosystems to absorb and store carbon in order to avoid even larger rises in atmospheric CO2 than are currently seen. Our carbon use models thus display greenhouse gas emissions.

Role in models

This map is used to identify the beneficiaries of CO2 sequestration in this storyline.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon released each year due to fossil fuel combustion.

Source

Spatially explicit data on greenhouse gas emissions exist for the United States. Globally, we use population density data multiplied by per capita emissions for the country or sub-national region of interest.
page.runninghead: Emitters benefit under a scenario of compensation

page.title: Soil C:N ratio
page.name: C/N ratio
page.description:
The ratio of carbon to nitrogen in soils influences the rate of sequestration of carbon from the vegetation, along with temperature ranges, land cover, vegetation types and evapotranspiration. In some ecosystems, carbon sequestration and storage are predicted to be greater under higher soil C:N ratio values.

Role in models

Data are used as input to the sequestration (source) model.

Representation

Data are a unitless ratio of soil carbon:nitrogen concentrations.

Source

The data are derived from the FAO's global soil database.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: Ratio of carbon to nitrogen in soils

page.name: Seasonality
page.title: Summer - Winter temperature range
page.description:
The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures can be a meaningful predictor of net primary production.

Role in models

These data were derived from global mean temperature data and are used as an input in the ARIES carbon models for both carbon sequestration and storage. Seasonality is predicted to affect carbon sequestration and storage, with greater sequestration and storage under lower seasonal temperature variability.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees centigrade.

Source

This map has been reclassified from globally available data provided by .
page.runninghead: The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures.

page.title: Successional Stage
page.name: Succession
page.description:
The stage of vegetation regrowth following a disturbance event. The rate of succession, type of late successional plant community, and importance of succession in predicting ecosystem carbon sequestration and storage will vary widely in different ecosystems. Generally, we predict greater carbon storage in late successional ecosystems and greater sequestration in early to mid successional ecosystems.

Role in models

.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project for western Oregon and Washington.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: The stage of vegetation growth influences CO2 uptake.

page.name: Tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Tree canopy data influences both carbon sequestration and storage in most environments. We generally predict greater carbon sequestration and storage in areas with greater tree canopy cover.

Role in models

The variable is used as input to compute carbon sequestration and storage distributions.

Representation

Data are the percentage of the ground surface covered by tree canopy.

Source

NLCD 2001 data in the United States; GLCF (University of Maryland) data used globally.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.title: Hardwood:Softwood ratio
page.name: Hardwood:Softwood
page.description:
Softwood and hardwood tree species grow at different rates, so they sequester and store atmospheric carbon in different ways. Generally, we assume softwoods will grow and sequester carbon at a greater rate early in their life, while hardwoods will grow more slowly (i.e., sequester less carbon annually) but will store more carbon in mature hardwood forests).

Role in models

The ratio of hardwood to softwood enters the probabilistic model of carbon sequestration and/or storage.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Reclassification of local forest type data.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Precipitation
page.title: Mean annual precipitation

description.p: Ecosystems in regions with greater mean annual precipitation generally have greater carbon sequestration and/or storage. Precipitation is particularly important in water-limited environments, where annual variation in precipitation strongly influences annual carbon sequestration.
Annual precipitation enters the probabilistic model of carbon sequestration and/or storage, particularly in arid environments.
The data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation.
Global or national-scale mean annual precipitation data.

page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.name: Fire
page.title: Fire Frequency

description.p: Fires are an important and in some cases predictable variable in determining release of carbon stored in biomass and soils.

The likelihood of deforestation and fire, combined with the quantity of stored carbon in an ecosystem, can predict the amount of stored carbon that is released during deforestation or fire. Fire is a strong influence on carbon dynamics in fire-adapted systems or those that have been altered by fire supression or invasive species, and is a weaker influence in colder and wetter climates.
State-level data on fire frequency and fire prone vegetation types.

page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil pH
page.title: Soil pH
page.description: h1. Role in models h1. Representation h1. Source

page.name: Population
page.title: Population density
page.description:
Population density can influences carbon storage. In tropical nations with high direct dependence on forests for firewood and other ecosystem goods, higher population density can lead to lower levels of forest carbon storage as woody debris and biomass are removed for direct human use.

Role in models

This variable is used to help estimate the quantity of carbon stored in vegetation.

Representation

Gaston et al. (1998) define the discretization used here to model population density effects on carbon levels.

Source

LANDSCAN global population density (Oak Ridge National Laboratory).
page.see-also:
Gaston, G., S. Brown, M. Lorenzini, and K.D. Singh. 1998. State and change in carbon pools in the forests of tropical Africa. Global Change Biology 4: 97-114.
The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: LANDSCAN 30m coverages produced by Oak Ridge Natl.Labs.
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.title: Level of forest degradation
page.name: Degradation
page.description:
Where forest degradation data are available, it can be used to train probabilistic models so that its effect is taken into consideration in predicting carbon sequestration and storage.

Role in models

Forest degradation data are available for Madagascar, a nation with high deforestation rates and levels of forest degradation. In degraded forests, we expect lower levels of carbon sequestration and storage.

Representation

Data are categorical, and identify degraded forest and savanna ecosystems.

Source

Foiben-Taosarintanini Madagasikara (FTM), Madagsacar national land cover.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: Degradation of forests can influence sequestration.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope class
page.description:
Soil on slopes can be more easily washed away, particularly in the absence of protective vegetation.

Role in models

Areas on steep slopes are predicted to have lower levels of soil carbon storage, all else being equal.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Data are derived from a global 90 m SRTM digital elevation map.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: Slope determines likelihood of soil washed away.

page.name: Fire Risk
page.title: Class of fire threat
page.description:
Fires are an important and in some cases predictable variable in determining release of carbon stored in biomass and soils.

Role in models

The likelihood of deforestation and fire, combined with the quantity of stored carbon in an ecosystem, can predict the amount of stored carbon that is released during deforestation or fire. Fire is a strong influence on carbon dynamics in fire-adapted systems or those that have been altered by fire supression or invasive species, and is a weaker influence in colder and wetter climates.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

State-level data on fire frequency and fire prone vegetation types.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different plant community or land cover types have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

Role in models

Data are used in some models to estimate differential carbon sequestration and/or storage in ecosystems such as forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

NLCD or other land use/land cover data.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: Vegetation type is a factor in defining sequestration and storage capacities.

page.name: Soil oxygen
page.title: Soil oxygen conditions
page.description:
The presence of oxygen (aerobic environments) in soils allows respiration to take place, with CO2 being released. In anaerobic environments such as wetlands, minimal soil respiration occurs, and greater buildup of soil carbon can occur (though generation of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas) often also occurs. Wetland degradation, such as through declining water tables, can also allow oxidation of soil carbon, reducing their carbon storage.

Role in models

Greater soil carbon storage is expected in wetland than upland environments, all else being equal. We currently do not consider the role of methane production by wetlands in the ARIES carbon models.

Representation

Data are represented as the presence/absence of wetlands.

Source

Land cover data, such as the U.S. NLCD, global GLC2000, or European CORINE datasets are used to identify the presence of wetlands.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: The presence of oxygen allows CO2-producing respiration to take place.

page.name: Deforestation
page.title: Risk of deforestation
page.description:
Areas at greater risk of deforestation is are likely to lead to greater stored carbon release.

Role in models

The likelihood of deforestation and fire, combined with the quantity of stored carbon in an ecosystem, can predict the amount of stored carbon that is released during deforestation or fire. Deforestation acts as a particularly strong influence in the model in tropical nations with higher deforestation rates and weaker land tenure and enforcement of legal limits on forest clearing.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

GLCF (University of Maryland).
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
